awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Can disturbance history predict plant species responses to environmental change?
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the greatest challenges of our time is anticipating how environmental change will alter the types of plants and animals we find within an ecosystem. At northern latitudes, winters have become shorter, snow depth has decreased, and temperatures have become more variable. This research project uses and continues long-term field surveys (65+ years) to determine whether these changing winters have affected the types of plants found within grassland communities.  This work examines which characteristics of species may make them most vulnerable to being lost and how land management activities, such as prescribed fires, may prevent their loss.  Project investigators will develop courses to train students about ecological complexity, and will develop workshops and webinars with local and national groups to inform the public about grassland ecology and conservation. Overall, this research examines how plant characteristics may influence their loss and persistence and determines how to best manage grasslands and savannas, two globally threatened and economically important ecosystems.   

This research examines the role that the functional traits of plants play in the responses and persistence of grassland species to changing winter conditions and environmental disturbances. Using data from historic and current surveys, this project examines how grassland plant communities in the North Eastern United States have changed over the past 65+ years and the degree to which these changes are explained by the frequency of fire disturbances and changing climatic conditions. Using a functional traits approach, manipulative field experiments will be used to determine species responses to disturbances (burning, mowing), winter conditions (snow depth), and their interactions, on species persistence, establishment, and community stability. This work examines the importance of freeze tolerance as a persistence related trait and tests the hypothesis that fire regimes are beneficial to preserving grassland diversity through their selection of stress-tolerant plants and influence on plant establishment and colonization rates. This work adds to our understanding of the ecology and management of grassland and savanna ecosystems and would make functional trait data available through several on-line resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Grasslands and savannas are globally important ecosystems that contain many rare and endangered species and provide important economic and ecosystem services. In temperate regions, these open-habitat ecosystems are found in areas with seasonal precipitation and maintained by frequent, low-intensity fires. Today, these ecosystems are one of the most imperiled due to habitat loss and fragmentation, the loss of routine fire, and changes in the amount and timing of rainfall and snowfall. In temperate regions, these shifts in precipitation are mainly taking place in the winter, resulting in less snow and longer falls and springs. Without snow, temperatures fluctuate more widely, increasing freezing risk for plants and animals. In addition, the loss of historic growing-season fire has resulted in human-generated prescribed fires that occur most often in the spring and fall seasons. It is, therefore, imperative to be able to  anticipate the impacts of altered winter conditions and the timing of prescribed fire on grassland plant communities to prevent biodiversity decline and allow effective management decisions to be made. 

 

This study utilized unique long-term observational and experimental data from tallgrass prairies to ask how tallgrass prairie and oak savanna plant communities change in response to altered winter conditions (reduced, ambient, increased snow cover) and the type (mowing, burning) and timing (spring, fall) of disturbances. In addition, the study assessed whether these changes affected some species more than others based on their life history characteristics. This study found that over the past 65+ years, species losses were greatest in prairies that did not experience routine prescribed fires. In addition, changing winter conditions appear to be affecting spring-blooming plant species more than species that bloom in summer or fall. The experimental study clearly demonstrated that soils were colder and also thawed earlier in the spring when there was less snow and when grasslands were burned in the fall. Plants grew less early in the season when soils were colder. Plant flowering was directly tied to when soils thawed in the spring. In addition, species adapted to tolerate stressful environments were more likely to increase in abundance in sites that were burned in the spring season. Stress-tolerant species also were more likely to colonize sites that had less snow and were burned in the fall. Vegetative spread by clonal plants occurred earlier in sites that were burned in the fall, including for the dominant grass species, Big Bluestem (Andropogon gerardii) and three common forbs, Common Milkweed, False Sunflower, and Rosinweed (Asclepias syriaca, Helianthus helianthoides, and Silphium integrifolium). It was more likely that plants flowered in unburned sites with ambient snow, but these same sites also had ~42% fewer individuals, resulting in lower reproduction overall. In general, plant roots appear to be less tolerant of cold than plant stems and leaves. We also found that there may be a potential tradeoff for plants that can avoid cold temperatures by growing rapidly vs. plants that can tolerate cold temperatures at the cost of growing more slowly. Reduced winter snowpack may have cumulative effects on plants that lead to lagged species losses.

 

This project was conducted in collaboration with agency and non-profit management partners. Results were communicated via research briefs, conferences, and field trips. All findings have been published in peer-reviewed journals with more on the way. This study also provided insight into how ecological textbooks can improve coverage of ecological complexity. Plant community and functional trait data have been or will be archived in publicly available databases.
